text: Matt in the shower, water streaming off his body. INT. ANA’S BEDROOM - MOMENTS LATER Ana, still wrapped up in the covers, watches Matt dress.
Stay.
Can’t. Got work and you got class.
We can call in sick. (play coughs)
Tempting but I gotta get down to the site.
They really can’t survive a day without you?

They can. Just not today. The New York office is sending another rep to make sure the hotel is coming together right and my boss needs me to play translator between him and the new foreman. He ties his shoes, finishing up.
Wait. I wanna look at you. He heads over. She stares at him with gorgeous green emeralds.
(beat) You look blurry.
That’s cause you’re not wearing your contacts.
Mmmm. ..good point. Matt smiles. Kisses her forehead. From under the bed, he produces a second edition copy of Mother Goose Children's Picture Book.
Happy six months.
My God, Matt.
Thought I forgot, huh?
No, I just didn’t know we were doing anything.
Well, I wanted to.
(examining her present) It’s amazing.
I know it’s not a first edition, but --
(not caring) Shut up. Where’d you find it?
This shop in Lapa.
I love it. Thank you.  They kiss.
Are you absolutely sure you have to go?
Yes. (kiss)
But I haven’t given you your present yet. She drags him back onto the bed and they disappear under covers. Kissing. Giggling. In love.
EXT. RIO DE JANEIRO - ESTABLISHING — MORNING

Fleeting shots of the city: Christ the Redeemer sitting a the Corcovado Mountain. The Maracana Stadium. The cable c at Sugarloaf. EXT. STREET MARKET —- MORNING Teeming with people, trading spices, hawking crafts. Matt negotiates with a VENDOR for some fruit. Caves. Hands ove more Real than he wanted to.
A crowded commuter bus drives by, spewing black smoke.
Matt stands in the back, doing the crossword puzzle.
Make that finishing the crossword puzzle.
Empty storefronts. Bodegas. Crowded corners packed with s locals. Matt hikes up a steep-sidewalk, talking on his ph
Hey, it’s me. (listens) Yeah, I know what time it is, but this is the only time I get to call. (MORE )

(listens) Yes, I do think it’s funny you have to get up early -- that’s why I signed up for the “piss off your friends and family plan”. I’m really happy with it. (listens) Okay, I’m sorry, do you want me to hang up? (listens) Alright then, tell me: how’s mom? He pauses, listening -- face falling a bit.

Okay. (listens) Okay. (listens) I don’t know. Hopefully. I’m getting pretty hammered with work lately, but maybe sometime next month. The checks are still coming to you, right? (listens) Yeah, I know that they’re not but it’s all I got right now. (listens) I know. And you? How you holding up? (listens) I hear ya. Stay strong baby brother. (listens) Okay. You too. Later. He hangs up, arriving:

A former hotel since converted into affordable housing un Nine stories high. Walking up, Matt finds his elderly NEIGHBOR struggling to wheel her laundry cart up the crac marble steps. In Portuguese; not subtitled:
Let me help you.
A Godsend. Thank you. He takes the cart, brings it up to the door and swings it open, letting them both inside.

Concrete walls, water-stained and graffiti-laced. Wires h from the ceiling like snakes. LOUD too. Walls so paper thin we can hear the baby WAILIN 5-C; the couple SCREAMING in 3-B; and the alarm still BUZ in 7-F. Matt arrives at a paint-chipped door at the end of the corridor -- the only apartment on the floor -- and remove laser-cut key from his pocket.

slightly larger than a regular key -- with a series of encrypted diodes along its edge. Matt slips it into the l entering: INT. APARTMENT —- CONTINUOUS An alarm BEEPS. Matt punches in a five-digit code -- shut it off. As soon as he closes the door -- -- SILENCE. The whole world just seems to DISAPPEAR. As he steps further inside, first thing we notice about t apartment -- -- how little there is to notice: bare walls; bare floors windows; no real furniture. It looks like it was robbed but since Matt isn’t worried, can only assume this is how it always looks.
Matt opens the fridge and tosses in the fruit he bought. lands beside fifteen unlabeled water bottles, six Red Bul cans -- -- and twelve packets of O+ BLOOD.

Pitch black until a light flickers on and a dozen monitor wink to life, presenting twelve views of the eight-room apartment. Matt sits down in a steel chair and picks up a secure red phone. A flat voice answers:
Satcom ten.
South America.
Designator?
Echo Bravo two three.
Transferring. Matt pops open a Red Bull -- CHK-THOCK! -- and takes a si We hear a SECOND VOICE. Female. Humorless. This is the:
Landlord.
This is House 7-R. We're open for business. A series of electronic clicks then:
Confirmed.
Any reservations?
Nothing in the registry.
Walk-in's?
Not expected.
Cancellations?
None as of yet.
Any word about my report?
What report?
I sent a report to Virginia in the overnight pouch.  A beat.
I have no record. Matt registers disappointment. A loud WHOOSH as we CUT TO
A black BMW X-3 whips past. A phone rings. INT. BMW — DAY DAVID BARLOW drives. 45. Horn-rimmed glasses. Always seri Even his underwear is ironed.
(answering into his Bluetooth) David Barlow.
Just around the corner from the apartment.
Hey, it’s me.
This is an open line.
I know the protocols.
Then why aren’t you following them?
Cause I didn’t want this to be an official call.
I’m not your handler, Matt.
As you’ve told me.
Several times.
I'll be quick. I just wanna know: what did Harlan think of my report?
Which report is that?
Key Surveillance Threats. I put it in an overnight pouch. He read it, right?
Matt --
You gave it to him, right? Barlow sighs.
No.
No? Why?
Because I didn’t need him giving it back to me, asking why I gave it to him in the first place.
You're saying he wouldn’t read it?
I’m saying no one would read it. It’s unsolicited. Barlow arrives at a fortified gate. Stops at the security arm.
What does that mean? A MARINE GUARD approaches his window. Barlow hands over h ID: David Barlow - South America - Central Intelligence Agency.

It means you’re not an agent, Matt. You're just a housekeeper. Stick to keeping houses. Operational intel is about eight rungs above your head. Matt -- stung. He’s ready for more responsibility, but is getting the chance. The guard hands Barlow back his ID.
Look, I gotta go. Don’t call me from this phone again. Barlow disconnects the call and drives up to: EXT. CIA HEADQUARTERS - LANGLEY -— CONTINUOUS
The leaves on the American Basswood trees are just starti to turn and fall. END INTERCUT. INT. PHONE BOOTH —- DAY Matt -- pissed -- hangs up the phone. CLUB MUSIC PULSATES.
Low-rent and seedy. MILAN MAXIM sits in a VIP booth. 33. Serbian. Two girls on either side, he drinks and smokes heavily.
An Audi with tinted windows pulls up in front of the club

steps out. 55. Ex-CIA field officer. This guy wears his years. Salt and pepper hair tucked underneath a hat. Stee grey eyes that burn with intensity -- deep and intelligen He may not move as fast as he used to -- but there’s stil plenty of fight in him. He shuts the car door. Heads into the club.
Where EMILE VARGAS watches Frost disappear from a top flo window. Ex-paramilitary. Gun for hire. Hard body. Not particularly large -- just lethal.
With Maxim and Frost in the club’s roped-off area. The gi are gone. Replaced by BODYGUARDS. Big. Brooding.  10. A waitress carries over a tray of tequila shots.
Drink? Frost shakes his head.
I’ll have yours then. He takes off four glasses while Frost takes everything in the gun bulges inside the bodyguard’s jackets; the sleazy clientele; the public drug use; needles; coke.
Can we move this along? Before I need a tetanus shot. Maxim tosses back two of the drinks, lights up a cigarett reaches down and brings up:
He sets it between them. Blows smoke up into the air.
The original eyes-only files. 100% unredacted intel. It’s a bargain at triple the price.
How'd you get it?
Who cares. Only thing that matters is I came through, yes?
Not if it’s tagged.

Impossible. It came from a clerk in their Haifa office. Look for yourself. Frost unlocks the case. Pops it open. INSIDE THE CASE: rubbing alcohol, cotton swabs, a tiny po and something that resembles a STAPLE GUN.
Some of your old bosses aren’t gonna like these files out in the open.  11.
I don’t care. That’s why they’re my old bosses. Frost -- satisfied -- closes the case.
So we good?

You're still here, aren’t you? Frost does a shot, grabs the case and moves away. We follow him out -- past drunk men, clawing at women. Disgusting assholes. Frost spies -- tucked into the corner -- a DRUNK. About h size. SLAPPING a stripper across the face. Frost stops, sizing the guy up. He turns to Frost. Locks eyes.
The fuck you looking at, puto? Frost refuses to look away. Instead, he calmly reaches in his pocket -- withdrawing a wad of cash.
INT. DIM ROOM — MOMENTS LATER Vargas -- at the window -- aiming through the lens of a M 12 Mod 0 SPR (Special Purpose Rifle).
Frost steps outside the club, Halliburton in hand.

A bullet rips into his head. He drops to the ground -- bl splattering the sidewalk. Bystanders SCREAM -- race away -- freaked. Except one: a LOCAL. He RUSHES up to the body -- grabbing the briefcase popping it open right there. It’s EMPTY. Local quickly looks to the body. Shirt’s a different colo Continues up to the face -- wait -- NOT FROST -- it’s THE DRUNK ASSHOLE -- BILLS sticking out of his pants pocket. Local peers up the window across the street but --  12. -- it’s empty. No Vargas. Just a blowing curtain.
Frost at the mirror. In front of him: the rubbing alcohol cotton swabs, pea-sized pod and staple gun.
He slips off his jacket -- rolls up his sleeve -- douses swab with alcohol and swabs his left arm. He takes the gun -- loads the pod -- and THWACK! -- INJEC SOMETHING into himself.

The back door of the strip club swings open. Frost moves briskly out -- sans jacket and hat. A cab drives up. Fros flags it. Steps inside. The car starts driving away. INT. CAB — SAME Frost stares ahead. Suddenly -- PHFT! -- a bullet rips through the driver’s head. He slumps down -- spinning the wheel --
-- CRASHING the car against a parked hydrant.

Frost JERKS forward -- SLAMS his head against the partiti Dazed, he shakes his eyes clear as -- PHFT! -- a bullet spider-webs the glass behind him -- just whizzing past hi head. He peers through the cracked glass. Looks up. Just catche FLASH OF LIGHT -- quickly ducks back down as -- -- PHFT! -- a bullet SHATTERS the window -- lands in the cushion beside Frost, glass raining in. Frost grabs the door handle. More GUNFIRE rains inside. H jerks it open -- climbs out --
-- and races into an alley just as -- PHFT! -- a bullet strikes the brick wall beside him.
on a ledge. He throws the gun over his shoulder. Climbs d
Frost BOMBS up to a tin fence. HOPS it in two steps. Land the other side as:

takes aim -- PHFT! -- thisclose to hitting him. Frost continues on -- never breaking stride -- SLAMMING I PEOPLE -- knocking them aside like a pinball. Vargas races after him. But when he rounds the same corne Frost just did -- -- Frost has VANISHED. Replaced by a STREET FAIR. Packed people. Loud. Noisy.
hiding behind a vendor's booth, watching Vargas search fo him. He pauses. Something’s not right.
drips onto his shoes. HIS BLOOD. Coming from A BULLET WOU on the side his stomach. Bad -- but he’ll live. Frost's face goes white. He puts his hand to his side. Applies pressure. Winces.

Shit. POP! POP! POP! POP! Frost whirls -- -- just tiny firecrackers that kids are throwing nearby, watching explode. Fuck that sounded just -- -- PHFT! PHFT! -- BULLETS -- whizzing by his head again, missing by mere inches. He doesn’t know where they’re coming from, but they’re getting closer -- SHOOTING through everything in their pa as they try to hit him. Frost takes off. Books --

Cars ZIPPING every which way. Frost RACES into the middle the street.  14. A delivery truck swerves around a corner. Frost LEAPS ont the back of it as -- -- Vargas emerges -- across the intersection -- taking sh at him and the vehicle -- PHFT! PHFT! A bullet STRIKES the back tire -- causes it to SKID -- an Frost to lose his grip. He LEAPS off -- knees bending into a roll -- POPPING up behind a tree -- directly across from:

Surrounded by a gate -- and SEVERAL U.S. MARINES standing a gate house. An American flag flaps above the entrance. Frost considers the building -- then looks out into the street. Sees -- -- SUNLIGHT GLEAMING OFF A SCOPE -- a few yards away.
staring through the sniper rifle from behind some bushes.

He looks back over to the embassy. A sanctuary. But how t fuck could he go there? He can’t go there right? But he’s armed and -- -- oh shit -- he’s bleeding bad now. He could pass out. G make a move. Fuck it. Better an embassy with plenty of ex than an exposed area with a sniper gun aimed at your head He looks down the street. A VAN is driving up. He has to this just right.

looking through the scope. He knows what Frost is gonna d Knows he has one shot. The van drives up. Perfect cover. Frost times it right. R out from behind the tree. Vargas can’t get a shot off -- view of Frost blocked by t van. And when the car clears -- Frost is GONE -- now deep on the other side of the embass gates. Vargas -- steaming -- as we CUT TO --  15. INT. U.S. EMBASSY —- ENTRY GATE - MOMENTS LATER

A security checkpoint. Passport and visa office on the ot side. THREE MARINE GUARDS stand post. Frost joins a short line. Eyes scanning everything: the sidearms; the security cameras; the X-ray machine; metal detectors. Finally it’s his turn. He steps up to a SECURITY OFFICER.

Passport please. Frost draws a passport. The officer opens it up. NEW ANGLE -- FROST’S PASSPORT Except the picture, nothing about it is real. Phony name. Phony birthday. Phony address. A near mint forgery. The Security Officer runs the code on the passport throug scanner. The light turns green and Frost is cleared to continue. He steps to the metal detector. Empties out his keys, pho and puts them in a plastic tray. Steps through the detect The alarm GOES OFF. A MARINE takes a wand to him.
Step over here, sir -- arms out, please. Frost -- no choice -- complies. Looks up. Sees a SECURITY CAMERA staring him down. INT. U.S. EMBASSY —- SECURITY OFFICE - SAME
TWO ARMED MARINES consult a dozen security videos. A near console runs recognition software on everyone's faces. Including Frost. INT. U.S. EMBASSY — ENTRY GATE - SAME

The guard runs the wand over Frost's legs: nothing. His chest: nothing. Left arm: nothing. Right arm -- -- BEEEEEEEEP! Guard pauses. Confused. He runs the wand again. Gets the same result. It’s coming from his INJECTI INT. U.S. EMBASSY — SECURTY OFFICE - SAME

The facial recognition software gets a hit.  16. Frost's picture POPS UP on the monitor -- a CIA file phot from ten years ago -- along with a MESSAGE -- FLASHING -- red: DETAIN -- DETAIN -- DETAIN. The CIVILIAN SECURITY CHIEF looks up from his paperback.
What the hell -- ? A second later, he’s on the phone. SECURITY CHIEF (CONT’D) I need a team to the southwest entry gate -- now. INT. U.S. EMBASSY —- ENTRY GATE - MOMENTS LATER
SECURITY -- on the move -- rush up to Frost. MARINE GUARD guns out, safeties off.

-- you -- hands up -- on the floor. Do it now! In a FLASH -- Frost gets KICKED to the linoleum. There’s KNEE in his back -- gun BARRELS at his head. His hands ar PULLED HARD behind his back -- ZIP-TIED.
Move an inch and I'll blow your fucking head off. He’s HOISTED UP off the floor as we CUT TO --
Dropping down from the sky -- clouds parting -- as we PRE

How certain are we about this? INT. CIA SITUATION ROOM —- SAME SIX INTELLIGENCE ANALYSTS -- including Barlow -- sit arou conference table. DEPUTY VICE DIRECTOR HARLAND WHITFORD, born for the job, holds court.
92% facial recognition match. Nose and chin are slightly different but it’s definitely him.  17. FULL SCREEN -- FROST’S CIA FILE PHOTO on a flat-screen monitor -- his agency bio logged underne
Jesus. Tobin fucking Frost.
He’s been off-grid, what, eight years?
Try ten.
Are we really this lucky?
Never been before.
Which just could mean we're due.
Luck had nothing to do with it. A double decade operative like Frost doesn’t walk back onto the reservation by chance.
Where Frost gets his bullet wound tended to by a MARINE DOCTOR as EMBASSY SECURITY stands guard.
Let’s pull any footage in and around the embassy we can get our hands on. Scrub every frame for any reason Frost had to go into that building.
In the meantime, we need to move him. We can’t ask the questions in the way we need to ask them in an embassy on American soil.
A government sedan rolls up to a security checkpoint. The driver -- DANIEL KIEFER, a senior intelligence agent -- h his ID to the MARINE GUARD.  18.
LINKLATER, a young and dangerously ambitious analyst, off his suggestion.
We can take him to a safe house. Bring in a Q&A team. Have them debrief him there. Work the exfil through Argentina. Whitford nods -- agreeing. INT. U.S. EMBASSY — HOLDING CELL — NIGHT
Frost -- alone -- sitting on a metal bed, hand running ov his injection scar.
Frost was one of the best operations men we've ever had. INT. U.S. EMBASSY — CORRIDOR - NIGHT
Kiefer is led down an access-only hallway by the Security Chief.
So make sure whoever we send knows who he’s talking to. I won't stomach stage fright. INT. U.S. EMBASSY — SECURTY OFFICE - NIGHT
Guards turn away from Frost -- visible on a monitor -- to door as Kiefer steps inside. Looks down at Frost -- then to the Chief -- all business.
We'll take it from here.
After ten years, this is one wrong in our history we’re finally gonna right. The sky RUMBLES and --
-- hard rain assaults the windows. Drips down the glass.  19.

Sparse: just a table, sofa, two chairs. Matt occupies one them. In front of him: six steel gun pieces and a stopwat Matt clicks the stopwatch. Shuts his eyes and starts putt together the pieces -- forming a Sig-Sauer pistol. He cli the stopwatch again, opens his eyes and checks his time: seconds. A good time -- unless you’re Matt.
Shit. He frowns. Knows he can do better.
Matt does a series of push-ups, body tightly muscled.
(grunting) -- seventy-three, seventy-four --
Matt does a series of sit-ups, drenched with sweat.
(grunting) -- eighty-one, eighty-two --
Matt stands on a stool, reaches up and switches out a spe lightbulb.
Bare: bed, dresser, bedside table. Matt changes the sheet
Matt sits at the island, reading three newspapers -- in t languages. His cell phone buzzes. He checks the display:
Hey. INTERCUT: INT. ANA’S BEDROOM — SAME
Ana -- on the phone -- getting dressed for a night out.
Hey, what are you doing?  20.
Just finishing up some work. You?
Going out. Gonna meet some friends at Baronetti in about an hour. You wanna join us?
I don’t wanna crash your party.
What if I want you to?
Then I’1l1 meet you in about an hour. Ana smiles.
Can’t wait. See you then. They exchange good-byes -- then click -- hang up. END INTERCUT. INT. SAFE HOUSE —- HALLWAY - MOMENTS LATER
Matt crosses the hallway -- entering:
ROOM) -— CONTINUOUS Matt steps inside -- gives a quick once-over of all the monitors. Sees nothing out of the ordinary. He steps back
INT. SAFE HOUSE — HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS
-- and gets four steps away before -- the intercom BUZZES Loud. Ear-piercing. Matt turns around -- curious. INT. SAFE HOUSE - SURVEILLANCE ROOM — MOMENTS LATER
Matt steps back inside. Sees -- on one of the screens:
standing outside, pelted by rain, ringing the apartment. hits a talk switch.
Yes?  21.
I need a room.
Do you have an account?
Daniel Kiefer, Atwater Insurance. Matt picks up the secure phone. We hear a familiar voice:
Satcom ten.
South America.
Designator?
Echo Bravo two three.
Transferring. Pause. Adrenaline now fully coursing through Matt’s veins
Landlord.
I need an urgent check on a Daniel Kiefer. K-I-E-F-E-R.
Account?
Atwater Insurance.
Kiefer looks up the street, sizing up the threat level of locals hanging outside a bar on the opposite block. INT. SAFE HOUSE —- SURVEILLANCE ROOM — SAME

Account confirmed. They hang up. Matt looks at a screen. Kiefer’s CIA dossie appears. Matt registers his intelligence ranking. Flinche  22. This guy’s serious. He hits the talk button. Looks at Kie on the monitor.
How many beds?
Six. Matt looks at another screen.
We PUSH IN on a street lamp. Inside: a concealed camera. INT. SAFE HOUSE —- SURVEILLANCE ROOM — SAME
A screen shows that camera’s vantage point: a BLACK VAN i parked in front.
Luggage?
Just a bag. Matt hits another switch -- BUZZ! -- and hurries out the room.

Kiefer swings open the door and holds it open for FIVE MO FIGURES -- rushing up. They’re part of a CIA EXTRACTION T Serious guys with serious gear. JARHEADS. They DRAG in wi them -- -- A LIMP BODY WEARING A HOOD. INT. SAFE HOUSE —- BEDROOM - SECONDS LATER

Matt punches in a lock combination on the closet, slides drawer open and withdraws a FIELD BOX. He slips in a key, opens up the box and withdraws A RED BACKPACK. He zips it open, revealing CASH, a PASSPORT, a SECURE CEL PHONE and a Sig-Sauer .9mm. He takes the gun. Slides it b Leaves the bag. Tucks the weapon behind his belt, pulling shirttails over it. Loud KNOCKING draws his ear to: INT. SAFE HOUSE - FOYER —- MOMENTS LATER
Matt opens the door to revel Kiefer, wet with rainwater.  23.
You the housekeeper? Matt nods.

I’m Kiefer. Where’s the guest room? INT. SAFE HOUSE —- KITCHEN - MOMENTS LATER A steel bucket is thrown into the sink. A hand flicks the faucet. Water fills up the bucket. INT. SAFE HOUSE - GUEST ROOM —- NIGHT
A padded room. Sound-proof. A single steel chair and tabl body gets thrown onto the chair. Hard. Makes a sound. Immediately gets cuffed and shackled. Hands and feet. A bag is removed from his head:
He locks eyes with a one-way mirror. A steely resolve.
Matt looks at Frost through the mirror -- taken aback.
That’s Tobin Frost.
You know him?
Yes, sir. He was my case subject my first year at the Farm. Ex- intelligence officer. Veteran agent of a six year undercover tour in the Soviet Union. A spy’s spy.

Until he went black in 2000. Since then, he’s given up assets; sold military intel to anyone with money: China, North Korea, al-Qaeda splinter groups, terror cells. The damage he’s done to our country is in the billions. INT. SAFE HOUSE - GUEST ROOM —- SAME
Frost stares directly ahead -- unfazed. Been here before.  24.
How'd you find him?
The only way you a find an operative like Frost. Luck. His face got scanned at the embassy.
Matt reacts. Something about that doesn’t track.
Langley wants him debriefed before check out. Matt finds that notion insane.
Excuse me sir, but an ex-field officer like Frost is not just gonna open up to you without some incentive.
I couldn't agree more. Just then, two Jarheads -- BECK and GREER -- cross up to room, toting the bucket filled with water and -- -- a_CAR BATTERY.
What’s that?
Incentive.
Frost's shoes are removed. Socks too. His tie is loosened his shirt torn open. Buttons fly. Electrodes are attached his chest and neck. His feet are placed in the bucket -- water spills out.
Matt -- watching this unfold through the glass -- horrifi
You can’t do this. There are rules. But when he turns -- Kiefer is already heading inside.
As long as he’s in my house, he’s in my care -- Kiefer! Kiefer ignores him, SHUTTING the door behind him. INT. SAFE HOUSE - GUEST ROOM — CONTINUOUS
Frost looks up. Eyes Kiefer stepping inside. He slides th chair out across from him. Takes a seat.
Matt watches them through the glass -- two pros regarding each other. Respect there. But not much.
I’m Daniel Kiefer, Mr. Frost. I’m here to make you aware of your rights. INT. SAFE HOUSE - GUEST ROOM —- SAME
You're being held under National Security Directive 72-C which means you have none. Per the Directive, I could literally lock you in a room and throw away the room. Frost -- unintimidated.

But before that happens, you’re gonna give us the names of all your resources, contacts and assets -- everyone you’ve done business with, traded intel with, sold secrets to, in the fifteen years since you turned traitor.
That’s gonna be a long list. Promise not to tell anyone? Kiefer -- annoyed -- maintains his composure.

I know you've read the books on our interrogation methods. Hell, you’ve written some of them. There’s no need wasting time with coercion; intimidation; bullying. You and I both know they won’t work on you. (MORE )
What will, I suspect, is tolerance. How much I have for you -- and how much you have for this. Greer cranks a dial on the car battery -- a current SURGE through Frost -- body ARCHING back in agony.
watching this, horrified. He knows Kiefer’s got a job to but doesn’t have the stomach for it.
With another twist of the dial -- the current abates. Fro sags.

We think there are at least three separate operations in the works that you may have compromised. We need to know how badly our security's been breached. We’re not gonna lose any more lives because of you. Again, Greer wrenches the dial. Electricity STREAMS. Fros HOWLS as power COURSES through his body. He LASHES around the chair, but gets SNAPPED back to it by the shackles.
Your contacts, Frost. I want the names. Another twist of the dial.
The names! The power shuts off. Frost, spent, but defiant.
You smell that? He spits on the floor. Looks up.
I think it’s me. He laughs. Kiefer -- pissed -- turns at Greer. Nods: agai He cranks the dial. Frost WAILS, FLAILING, SCREAMING, IN AGONY, until -- -- Kiefer SEES something.  27.

on Frost’s arm: the INJECTION SCAR. He turns to Greer. Signals him to cut the power. He obeys Frost is slumped over in the chair by now, exhausted. Kie grabs his arm. TWISTS it. He looks over the mark. Blinks. Realizes what it means.
Get me a knife. But before anyone can do anything -- -- the lights SHUT OFF -- plunging the room into DARKNESS
Black here too. A beat and the emergency back-up lights h to life, illuminating Matt, confused. INT. SAFE HOUSE —- GUEST ROOM —- SAME
Kiefer turns to the Jarheads.
Come with me.
The door swings open and Kiefer rushes out with Beck and Greer, ordering Matt to:
Watch him. They step out. Matt turns to Frost, head bowed, exhausted
A van with tinted windows screeches to a stop out front. INT. SAFE HOUSE - SURVEILLANCE ROOM — MOMENTS LATER
Jarheads CRAIG, VIRKLER and VELEZ are at the bank of surveillance monitors, struggling to switch them on, but they’re all BLACK. Kiefer rushes in, under:
What the hell’s going on?
I don’t know -- we’re dark. Whole building’s gone black.  28.
The back of the van EXPLODES OPEN. TEN MERCENARIES bomb out. All heavily armed with machine guns. Locals. Faces covered with bandanas. Tats wherever there’s skin. They storm up to the building.
Motion sensors? Virkler checks a console. Turns to Kiefer. Look says it a they’re fucked.
shit. INT. APARTMENT BUILDING - STAIRWELL — NIGHT
As the gunmen make their way up a staircase, inching towa the apartment -- we CUT TO -- INT. SAFE HOUSE - GUEST ROOM —- SAME
Matt tries to make sense of what’s happening, looking aro on edge.
You better have an exit strategy. Matt turns to Frost. Shakes his head. Tries to convince himself:
This is a safe house. Frost shakes his head.
Not for long. off Matt -- CUT TO --

Kiefer and the five Jarheads take up defensive positions, around corners, in doorways, raising weapons, switching o safeties, tickling triggers. Each of them getting loose -- trying not to freeze up.  29.

Beck aims his gun at the front door -- listening with bat breath at the SOUND of approaching FOOTFALLS -- which END the door. Someone’s on the other side. He tightens the grip on his Heckler and cracks his neck, ready. Everything that happens now -- happens fast: BOooooooM! The floor beneath his feet EXPLODES! Just GOES in a heartbeat. charging into the room. It’s about to be two against one Frost -- -- KICKS the African back. He hits the elevator controls. door CLOSES -- -- just as the Albanian reaches them -- left watching as lift rises up to another floor. He then turns -- seeing:

How'd you --

After I shot you, you needed a place to mend. Some place quiet. You've never been shot before. You were confused. Scared. So you did what all people do when they are confused and scared. You retreated to some place familiar. It was late. She was probably home. You had to explain away the blood and there are only so many lies for why you didn’t go to the hospital when a bullet kisses your skull. I never met Ana but I don’t peg you as the type of guy who dates a girl who takes news like that well. Jesus, he’s good. He finishes up.  88.
It's for the best though. Like I said, there’s no real loyalty anymore. Everyone betrays everyone. He walks over to a sink -- runs the water -- cleaning the blood off his hands.

You don’t know what you’re talking about.
I know you weren’t always like this.
Is that what you wrote in your case study?
Maybe. You didn’t have money problems. Or drug problems -- sex problems. You weren’t a deviant. So why’d you do it? Why’d you turn?

You think it was one thing? It’s never one thing. Like you, I joined the agency bright-eyed and innocent. Wrapped myself up in the flag. Got weepy at the memorial wall. But over time, the game changed. I lost track of the lies. The politicians took over. No one believes in anything anymore. It was all bullshit. We weren't solving problems. We were creating them. And I wasn’t gonna be a part of it.
So why not just walk away clean?
And let all that training go to waste? At least now I get to pick the assignments I want -- when I want -- and get paid a shit load more for it.  89. Matt’s face registers disappointment.

Please. Don’t look at me like I just told you there was no Santa Claus. Believe me, no one’s soul, no matter how decent at first, can stay intact after being chiseled away at for so long. Matt considers that -- as we CUT TO -- INT. CIA HEADQUARTERS - PARKING LOT — NIGHT
Linklater crosses the lot, footfalls ECHOING. He has his phone to his ear, in mid-conversation:

It’s me. I’m on my way to the airport now. (listens) The problem isn’t Weston. It’s Barlow. I gotta find a way not to feel his breath on my neck so I can finish this on my own. He pulls out his keys, shutting the alarm to his parked Mercedes S-Class. LINKLATER (CONT’D) Yeah, I know he’s a hard-ass but so am I. (listens; gets to his car) Alright. Will do. Later. VARIOUS SCENERY whips by as we travel further away from R acres of empty land; farms; gardens -- all bathed in gold light. A BUS passes by, old and beat-up.
A cattle car packed with travelers. Some sleeping. Some smoking. All sweating.
Matt rides with Frost in silence. Frost watches the scene whip by the window: a beautiful vista. Quiet, until:
That still doesn’t look too good. Frost turns to him, then looks down at his stomach wound.  gl.
I'll survive. He stares back out.
You know something, Frost: I don’t think you're half as cynical as you make yourself out to be.
Is that what you think?
Yeah. Remember, I’ve read your op reports. I think if someone gave you a clear directive -- something you knew to be the right thing -- you'd do it today.
But whose to say what the right thing is? The same people who think you're a terrorist? Matt doesn’t have an answer. Matt nods.
Do you wanna make agent?
Then let me be your best friend in the world and tell you something you need to know: you never will.
Is that right?
You don’t have the skill set for it.
(defensive) I'm bringing you in, aren’t I?
I didn’t say you didn’t have any skills. Just not the right one.
Which is?
Detachment. You’re too invested.
And that’s a bad thing?
For an idealist? No. For a field officer, there’s nothing worse. And you know it too -- or else you would've killed him.
Who?
The freelancer. You could’ve killed him, you should've killed him, but you didn’t kill him.
That’s because I didn’t have to.
And you think that makes you noble?
I think it makes me not you.
Exactly. Don’t make the same mistakes I did, Matt. You’re too good a man for this work of ours. He turns forward -- looking ahead.
Go back to Ana. Get out before you forget why you got in. They drive on in silence. Matt thinks about what Frost sa wondering if -- indeed -- this is the job for him.

EXT. WASHINGTON DC - ESTABLISHING — DAY
Fleeting shots of the various monuments as we PRELAP:
We read the files you recovered. INT. CIA HEADQUARTERS - WHITFORD’S OFFICE - SAME
Matt -- arm in a sling -- bruises healing -- stands befor Whitford and Graff.
Turned up quite a few surprises, not the least of which involved Barlow. According to the documents, he sold military secrets to Israeli intelligence under the handle “Bvner.” This is news to Matt.
He was a double?

(nodding) Bastard had us all fooled. Once the laundry list was stolen, Mossad tasked him with its retrieval. After Barlow found out the deal was going down in Brazil, he enlisted Vargas for local support. At least Frost paid us the courtesy of stabbing us in the chest. Matt says nothing.
I have to say -- in light of everything -- I was distressed to hear you're leaving us.  110.
I think it’s for the best.

We've already picked up the bill on your mother’s medical expenses, but in addition, we can offer you practically any assignment you want. You can write your own ticket here. You sure we can’t change your my mind? Matt shakes his head.
This isn’t for me.
I think you’re fooling yourself.
No. I was fooling myself. He heads for the door.
One last question. Matt stops. Looks back.
Why did Frost came back for you? Matt has thought long and hard about this.
It was the right thing to do. He heads out. Whitford turns to Graff -- scoffs in disbel
What the hell does that mean?
